bibdata.title: Add discrete fields for new Change The Subject Headings

comments.body:
For the existing fields **lc_subject_display, subject_unstem_search, subject_topic_facet** :

**In production:**
lc_subject_display: [
"Refugees—Drama",
"Africans—Europe—Drama",
"Undocumented immigrants—Europe—Drama",
"Africa—Emigration and immigration—Drama"
],

**Proposed:**
lc_subject_display: [
"Refugees—Drama",
"Africans—Europe—Drama",
"Africa—Emigration and immigration—Drama"]

-----------
**In production:**
"subject_unstem_search": [
    "Refugees—Drama",
    "Africans—Europe—Drama",
    "Illegal aliens—Europe—Drama",
    "Africa—Emigration and immigration—Drama",
    "Undocumented immigrants—Europe—Drama"
],

**Proposed**:
subject_unstem_search: lc_subjects + local_subjects
subject_unstem_search: [
"Refugees—Drama", 
"Africans—Europe—Drama", 
"Illegal aliens—Europe—Drama", 
"Africa—Emigration and immigration—Drama",
"Undocumented immigrants—Europe—Drama"
]

-----------
**In production:**
"subject_topic_facet": [
    "Refugees",
    "Africans",
    "Europe",
    "Undocumented immigrants",
    "Africa",
    "Emigration and immigration"
],

**Proposed**
"subject_topic_facet": [
    "Refugees",
    "Africans",
    "Europe",
    "Undocumented immigrants",
    "Africa",
    "Emigration and immigration"
  ]

- The catalog will need to use subject_display for 'Subjects' and not lc_subject_display, after a full reindex; So that all the records have the same fields updated with the correct terms. This will have a downtime in the search for some records that they get updated thorugh the incremental job, since we don't have a separate traject_config to use during indexing. see https://github.com/pulibrary/bibdata/issues/1626
- If we want to implement this now we would need to use a different name for the 'lc_subject_display' , for example lc_subject_display_new, so that we dont break the catalog which is looking lc_subject_display. Then when the time comes to run a full reindex we will do the adjustment to the catalog to look subject_display. 
- In a second full reindex we can update the lc_subject_display and remove the lc_subject_display_new without any downtime in the catalog.

We can discuss this further in our meeting; if we want to close this issue in this workcycle, we will follow @mzelesky's proposal but we will call it 'lc_subject_display_new'. 
When we decide to run a full reindex: 
1. we create the new catalog index collection; 
2. we swap the index; 
3. we have an orangelight PR ready to look for 'subject_display' instead of 'lc_subject_display' for 'Subjects' in the record page. (open a new issue for 3. when we decide how to proceed with this issue )

figgy.title: Handle archival object not being found
Resource has ark with `pdf` appended to it and cannot mark complete

comments.body:
It looks like this object is pulling a bad ark from the catalog record

https://github.com/pulibrary/figgy/blob/3b7e1b4575f36c4244c74258a1ae2b976bf81ebc/app/change_set_persisters/change_set_persister/apply_remote_metadata.rb#L49

For this case, there was one figgy resource that is a publicly-viewable table of contents, listed in the 856 of the catalog record, which provides that link to the pdf.

Now we want to provide the actual resource to a patron via restricted special collections access. The 856 was pulled from the catalog record during metadata sync and placed as the local identifier.

We had to nil out the resource.identifier, save it manually in the rails console, and then it could be marked complete through the resource page as usual and get assigned a different / new ark.

pul_solr.title: solr backups not running on solr7 production

comments.body:
@tpendragon investigated, backups are failing on Solr 2/3 because the mounted drive for backups is not owned by the correct user.

All three Solr servers should be capable of running the backups as the leader of the cluster. Fix the current mounting system:
- [x] mount diglibdata1 only once, as `/mnt/solr_backup`
- [ ] ~~use NFS instead of CIFS~~
- [x] ensure the owner of the `/mnt/solr_backup` directory is the local `deploy` user, which may have a different UID on each box
- [x] update `/etc/fstab` so the new configuration will survive a reboot

We discussed this in the weekly Ops meeting today, and decided to leave the drives mounted using CIFS. I'd originally suggested we change the mount type because we thought the mount was unreliable. Since that was not, in fact, the problem, we will continue to use CIFS for now.
